text.headline: IUPUI is established
text.text: Indiana University and Purdue University merge their many programs and schools to create IUPUI.

text.headline: Maynard K. Hine, D.D.S.
text.text: In 1969 Indiana University and Purdue University merge to create IUPUI and Maynard K. Hine, D.D.S., becomes the first chancellor.

text.headline: Defining the urban university
text.text: In the early 1970s, then-Chancellor Hine compiled a list of all community engagement activities from each school at IUPUI. This shaped IUPUI's attitude and mission to serve Indianapolis.

text.text: IUPUI holds first commencement, granting 1,535 degrees

text.headline: Celebrating MLK
text.text: IUPUI's Black Student Union organizes the first recognition event in memory of slain civil rights leader Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with a day of activities.

text.headline: Law school moves
text.text: IU School of Law–Indianapolis moves onto the IUPUI campus.

text.headline: Indy meets Columbus
text.text: IUPUI begins sending faculty to Columbus, Indiana, to teach a select number of courses. Over the years, more courses are added to the Columbus curriculum, and some IUPUI faculty move to Columbus to teach full-time.

text.headline: Normal to extraordinary
text.text: The Normal College of the American Gymnastic Union was a school where young men and women learned to be physical education teachers. The college was based on the principles of Friedrich Ludwig Jahn and was associated with the Turnverein.
text.secondary_text: It moved to Indianapolis from Milwaukee in 1907 and was located in The German House (Das Deutsche Haus). Students at the college took classes not only in physical exercise but also in the sciences (such as anatomy and physics), humanities (history and literature), and fine arts (singing and dancing). In 1941 the Normal College became affiliated with Indiana University. Renamed the Indiana University School of Physical Education in 1973, it is the oldest continuously operating school of physical education in the country.

text.headline: Hot off the press
text.text: The campus student newspaper, The Sagamore, is first published.
text.secondary_text: It is predated by newspapers of the merged campuses: Onomatopoeia for the Downtown Campus of Indiana University–Indianapolis, and The Component for the Purdue University–Indianapolis Extension, later 38th Street campus.

text.headline: The undergraduate campus
text.text: Undergraduate campus opens, consisting of Cavanaugh Hall, Lecture Hall, and University Library.

text.headline: New services for students
text.text: The Office of Student Services opens, helping students make the most of their time on campus.

text.headline: Physical education has a moment
text.text: The School of Physical Education in Indianapolis becomes autonomous from the School of Health, Physical Education, and Recreation on the Bloomington campus.

text.headline: The early days of men's basketball
text.text: IUPUI's intercollegiate athletics program begins with the creation of a men's basketball team. The team chooses the name 'Metros' to reflect IUPUI's metropolitan location.

text.headline: SPEA, liberal arts, and more
text.text: Four new schools are established on the IUPUI campus: the IU School of Public and Environmental Affairs, the IU School of Liberal Arts, the Purdue School of Science, and the Purdue School of Engineering and Technology.

text.headline: The beginnings of the School of Education
text.text: The IUPUI Division of Education is established. Three years later, in 1975, the division merges into a single IU School of Education.

text.headline: The History of Home Comfort
text.text: Art student Carol Yattaw paints a mural on the foyer wall of Bryant Manufacturing Company in Indianapolis. Entitled 'The History of Home Comfort,' the mural tells the story of man's attempt to make his home more comfortable, from cave dwellers around a bonfire to pilgrims at a fireplace to modern Americans enjoying air conditioning. Her commission comes as the result of a competition among third-year art students at the John Herron Art Institute, now the Herron School of Art and Design.

text.headline: Glenn W. Irwin, Jr., M.D.
text.text: Glenn W. Irwin, Jr., M.D. is named second chancellor of IUPUI
text.secondary_text: During his deanship, Dr. Irwin's focus on medical education resulted in the development of the 'Indiana Plan' in the 1960s, the first comprehensive medical education program of its kind. The 'Indiana Plan' established seven additional campuses where the first two years of medical education were taught in collaboration with the science faculty. In an effort to address physician shortages in underserved areas and to serve our aging population, the School of Medicine expanded the statewide system created by Dr. Irwin in 2012 by adding third- and fourth-year options to those campuses.

text.text: The School of Business is reorganized on two campuses: IUPUI and Bloomington.

text.headline: A cure for testicular cancer
text.text: A young, unknown oncologist at the Indiana University School of Medicine, Lawrence Einhorn, adds an experimental drug to the chemotherapy regimen for testicular cancer.
text.secondary_text: Seemingly overnight, a disease that was almost universally fatal becomes eminently curable. Tumors dissolved within days. Over the years, with Distinguished Professor Lawrence Einhorn's cisplatin chemotherapy regimen, the cure rate of testicular cancer has increased from 10 percent to nearly 95 percent today.

text.text: The Charles S. Peirce Project, a documentary editing project to publish the complete works of the influential philosopher, moves to IUPUI from Texas Tech University. Peirce (1839–1914) is recognized worldwide as one of humanity's most rigorous, versatile, and seminal thinkers.

text.headline: The traveling fireplace
text.text: The IU School of Law–Indianapolis was originally housed in the Maennerchor Building at Michigan and Illinois Streets. When the school moved to its new building at New York and Blackford Streets (now the site of Eskenazi Hall), the large fireplace from Maennerchor (shown with Dean Cleon Foust in this 1970s photo) was moved into the new building. In 2001, the fireplace was moved into Inlow Hall, the law school's newest home. Sharing the fireplace's distinction of having been in all three buildings is the law school's longest-serving faculty member, Lawrence A. Jegen III, the Thomas F. Sheehan Professor of Tax Law and Policy.

text.headline: A visit from Dan Quayle

text.secondary_text: Quayle graduated from the Robert H. McKinney School of Law in 1974. Later he went on to become the 44th Vice President of the United States serving alongside President George H. W. Bush.

text.headline: Elks Cancer Research Center opens
text.text: A little over a decade before the IU Simon Cancer Center is established, the Elks Cancer Research Center opens. The Indiana Elks Foundation is a major supporter of cancer research in Indiana, providing more than $4 million to fund such research at IU.

text.headline: Preserving reproductive function in men
text.text: Distinguished Professor John Donohue, M.D., develops a nerve-sparing surgery for urologic cancers. This procedure has since been proven to preserve reproductive function in men.

text.headline: Talent scouting for Hoosiers
text.text: IUPUI hosts a callout for extras for the movie Hoosiers.

text.headline: Hosting the Big Ten
text.text: IUPUI hosts the Big Ten swim meet.

text.headline: Research in the 1980s
text.text: A student at the Indiana University School of Medicine conducts research.

text.headline: Home of the National Sports Festival
text.text: IUPUI faculty and staff help plan the National Sports Festival, which is held at venues on campus, including Carroll Stadium and the Natatorium.

text.headline: Research for alcohol abuse
text.text: Funded by a grant from the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, the Indiana Alcohol Research Center is created to focus on the biomedical and psychosocial factors that contribute to alcohol abuse and alcoholism.

text.headline: Curing anemia in children
text.text: Hal Broxmeyer, Ph.D., develops the use of human umbilical cord blood as a source of stem cells for transplantation, and he personally prepares the cells for the first cord blood transplant that cures a patient with Fanconi anemia, a precancerous, genetic condition in children.

text.headline: First Challenger Scholarships awarded
text.text: The IUPUI Challenger Scholarship Program is established in memory of the seven astronauts who died aboard the Challenger space shuttle in 1986. The program awards full-tuition scholarships to 35 outstanding IUPUI students majoring in science, engineering and technology, social science, and education.

text.headline: A new school for fundraising
text.text: The Fund Raising School moves from San Francisco to IUPUI to be part of the Center on Philanthropy.

text.headline: A stadium fit for Olympians
text.text: The Olympic Trials for track and field events are held at IUPUI's Carroll Stadium.

text.headline: The Polis Center
text.text: The Polis Center is established at IUPUI to link two types of expertise, academic and practical, for the benefit of communities in Indiana and elsewhere.

text.headline: $20 million in new construction
text.text: The IU Board of Trustees approves $20 million for phase-three construction of the Science, Engineering, and Technology building project, as well as planning for a new IUPUI University Library.

text.headline: Center for the Study of Religion and American Culture
text.text: The Center for the Study of Religion and American Culture is established with a grant from Lilly Endowment to create a national, interdisciplinary research and public teaching institute.

text.headline: Enrollment continues to grow
text.text: The 26,000th student registers for classes at IUPUI.

text.headline: University Library groundbreaking
text.text: Administrators and dignitaries break ground for IUPUI University Library.

text.headline: Medical school partnership
text.text: The School of Medicine initiates its partnership with Moi University Medical School in Eldoret, Kenya.

text.headline: Off-campus learning opportunities
text.text: The Community Learning Network is established to bring learning opportunities to off-campus sites throughout Central Indiana.

text.headline: Breaking ground on phase three
text.text: Administrators and dignitaries break ground for phase three of the Science, Engineering, and Technology buildings project.

text.headline: IU Hospital and Outpatient Center
text.text: IU Hospital and Outpatient Center is completed.

text.headline: Improving urban living
text.text: The IU Center for Urban Policy is founded at IUPUI to examine society's daily and pressing issues: neighborhood empowerment, community safety, the economic impact of the arts and sports, land use, and drinking water infrastructures—just to name a few.

text.headline: Wheelchair races and more at the Paralympic Games
text.text: IUPUI hosts the 1992 Paralympic Games at the Michael A. Carroll Track and Soccer Stadium. In the photo above, Frank Epperson competes in the wheelchair races. Epperson now works at Indiana University as the ADA employment consultant.

text.headline: More service, more learning
text.text: The Office of Service Learning is instituted to support the development of service learning classes at IUPUI.

text.headline: Purdue programs complete move
text.text: Purdue programs complete move to main IUPUI campus.

text.headline: NCAA Division II
text.text: IUPUI joins NCAA Division II.

text.headline: A day of caring
text.text: The United Way Day of Caring begins as the first campuswide volunteer service event.

text.headline: University Library dedication
text.text: University Library is dedicated.

text.headline: Volunteerism grows
text.text: The Office of Community Service opens to promote voluntary service among IUPUI students, faculty, and staff.

text.headline: Minority Achievement Scholarship program
text.text: The Minority Achievement Scholarship program is established. It was later renamed the Norman Brown Diversity and Leadership Scholars Program to honor the associate director of the IUPUI Office of Undergraduate Admissions who had helped develop it.

text.headline: Serving Indianapolis early and often
text.text: Service has been ingrained in the culture of IUPUI since 1922, when Sigma Theta Tau, a service fraternity for nursing, was started by six nursing students.

text.headline: Wood Fountain
text.text: Wood Fountain is commissioned and completed on the IUPUI campus along New York Street, surrounded by brick pathways. The fountain is 100 feet long on each of its four sides.

text.headline: Spring House Calls begin
text.text: The IU School of Medicine begins Spring House Calls, taking medical students into three inner city neighborhoods for voluntary yard work and landscaping for elderly, disabled, and minority homeowners. Spring House Calls remains the longest-running service learning project at the School of Medicine.

text.headline: Tutoring youth in Indianapolis
text.text: IUPUI Chancellor Gerald Bepko endorses President Clinton's America Reads Challenge. IUPUI students begin tutoring youth in kindergarten through eighth grade, through strategic use of community work-study programs.

text.headline: A place for ideas and invention
text.text: The Advanced Research Technology Institute is created to bring technologies and innovations developed by IU researchers to market, and to handle IU's intellectual property, trademarks, and business development activities. It is later named the IU Research and Technology Corporation.

text.headline: An office for women
text.text: The Office for Women is created to improve the campus environment for women at IUPUI.

text.headline: Targeted cancer care
text.text: The Indiana Cancer Pavilion is dedicated. It houses the departments of urology, medicine, obstetrics and gynecology, and surgery under one roof to deliver patient care, with special clinics targeted at specific cancers, including a Women's Cancer Center, the first in Indiana to provide comprehensive health services to women with breast and reproductive organ cancers.

text.headline: National model for urban universities
text.text: IUPUI is emerging as a national model for urban universities. Innovative. Creative. These special qualities not only contribute to a great urban university; they are a beacon for students who embrace all that is best about IUPUI. Former IU President Myles Brand, 1996 State of the University Address

text.headline: University College established
text.text: University College is created by the IUPUI Faculty Council.

text.headline: A lab for all things CD-ROM and VHS
text.text: Herron School of Art and Design opens a new, state-of-the-art Image Visualization Lab. Chancellor Gerald Bepko writes in his newsletter that the new lab 'instructs students in the use of CD-ROM, digital photography, videotape editing, and the production of top-quality web pages, magazines, and documentaries.'

text.headline: Aging research
text.text: The IU Center for Aging Research is established to focus on the health and well-being of older adults. Increased technology through the years allows the center to explore new models of care for late life depression, dementia, delirium, and other common geriatric syndromes.

text.headline: Special delivery: the Leskell Gamma Knife
text.text: The first Leksell Gamma Knife—a 20-ton, noninvasive technology that uses radiation as a 'scalpel' to arrest the growth of tumors deep inside the brain—arrives at the IU Medical Center. It is the only one in Indiana and one of only 28 in the nation.

text.headline: Moving on up
text.text: IUPUI Jaguars move up to NCAA Division I and join the Mid-Continent Conference (what is now known as the Summit League).

text.headline: Clarian Health partnership
text.text: University Hospital joins with Methodist Hospital and Riley Hospital for Children to form Clarian Health, a nonprofit organization that operates together and with the IU School of Medicine.

text.headline: Lightning speed
text.text: A dedicated team of students, faculty, and staff from the Purdue School of Engineering and Technology at IUPUI competes against Ohio State University, the University of Notre Dame, and other schools in a unique racing series called 'formula lightning' that features high-performance electric vehicles.

text.headline: Kelley gets its name
text.text: The IU School of Business is renamed the Kelley School of Business after alumnus E.W. Kelley. Schools on both the Bloomington and IUPUI campuses take the new name.

text.headline: Partnering with our neighbors
text.text: The Office of Neighborhood Partnerships is established.

text.headline: Best in the Midwest
text.text: The IUPUI chapter of the National Society of Black Engineers is named the best in the Midwest and is recognized for its range of community service and outreach programs, including weekend Internet workshops for inner-city high school students.

text.headline: Documenting the Frederick Douglass Papers
text.text: The Frederick Douglass Papers Edition documentary-editing project moves to IUPUI from West Virginia University. It is part of the Institute for American Thought.

text.headline: Jaguar pride
text.text: The jaguar becomes the official mascot of IUPUI.

text.headline: Racing for the Cure
text.text: Participants in the Indianapolis Susan G. Komen Race for the Cure run through IUPUI's campus along New York Street

text.headline: National Cancer Institute
text.text: IU Cancer Center receives National Cancer Institute designation.

text.headline: Service-based scholarships
text.text: The Community Service Scholarship Program (now named the Sam H. Jones Scholarship Program) is established to support students committed to civic engagement.

text.headline: A huge win for Men's Soccer
text.text: The men's soccer team wins the Mid-Continent Conference Tournament. They play in the NCAA national championship tournament, a first for IUPUI athletics.

text.headline: Exchange program with South Africa
text.text: IUPUI is one of 12 universities selected to participate in the Community Higher Education Service Project. IUPUI hosts a team from the University of the Free State in South Africa and, in exchange, sends a consulting team to South Africa.

text.headline: Dental public health
text.text: The Division of Community Dentistry is founded to promote student competence in dental public health skills.

text.headline: Inlow Hall opens
text.text: Lawrence W. Inlow Hall opens as the new home of the law school.

text.headline: Center for Service and Learning established
text.text: The Center for Service and Learning is formed by combining the Office of Service Learning, the Office of Community Service, and the Office of Neighborhood Partnerships.

text.headline: Recognized by AASCU
text.text: The American Association of State Colleges and Universities selects IUPUI as a campus that demonstrates a high level of commitment to civic engagement.

text.headline: The first ever Jagathon
text.text: IUPUI holds its first ever Dance Marathon, called Jagathon, to help children with life-threatening illnesses. The money raised through the event is given directly to Riley Hospital for Children through the Children's Miracle Network. Over the next 15 years, Jagathon raises over $760,000.

text.headline: Medical service learning expands
text.text: The Office of Medical Service Learning is founded to expand the IU School of Medicine curriculum to include service learning in local communities.

text.headline: Excellence in service learning
text.text: U.S. News & World Report, in their America's Best Colleges edition, recognizes IUPUI for its excellence in service learning programs, an honor that becomes an annual tradition.

text.headline: The beginnings of the Breathalyzer
text.text: In 1938, IU School of Medicine biochemist Rolla Harger unveiled the 'drunkometer,' the first practical roadside breath-testing instrument to measure alcohol levels in people suspected of being impaired while driving. Twenty years later, IU alumnus Robert Borkenstein, a captain with the Indiana State Police, invented a more portable version of the tool called the Breathalyzer. When Borkenstein passed away in 2002, the New York Times published his obituary and a brief history of the invention, citing his collaboration with the IU School of Medicine. Today, the Breathalyzer is a trademarked product, but also used as a generic term for blood alcohol tests.

text.headline: Men's basketball advances to NCAA
text.text: The men's basketball team wins the Mid-Continent Conference Tournament. They advance to the NCAA tournament.

text.headline: Chancellor Bantz
text.text: Charles R. Bantz, Ph.D., is named fourth chancellor of IUPUI.

text.headline: Forensics program offered
text.text: The Forensic and Investigative Sciences program is established, offering the first forensic science degree program in Indiana.

text.headline: Informatics and Communications Technology Complex opens
text.text: The Informatics and Communications Technology Complex opens, and becomes home to the School of Informatics and Computing at IUPUI.

text.headline: Collaborating with the city
text.text: IUPUI signs a Memorandum of Understanding with the City of Indianapolis in support of a collaborative relationship that provides credible, in-depth analysis and research for more informed decision making.

text.headline: Solutions for area businesses and nonprofits
text.text: The IUPUI Solution Center opens as a means to facilitate connections with area businesses and nonprofit organizations.

text.headline: George Hill, former Jag
text.text: Basketball player George Hill begins his freshman year at IUPUI. He will lead the IUPUI Jaguars to a school-record 26 wins and the Summit League Tournament finals. Hill later plays for the Indiana Pacers.

text.headline: $1 billion raised for IUPUI
text.text: The Campaign for IUPUI, a comprehensive fundraising campaign launched under Chancellor Gerald Bepko, ends after raising more than $1 billion—a record at that time for a public Indiana campus.

text.headline: Herron moves to campus
text.text: Sidney and Lois Eskenazi Hall becomes the new home for the Herron School of Art and Design. The move of Herron from 16th Street means that, after 36 years of imagining and planning, all of the IUPUI schools are together on one campus.

text.headline: Bantz earns a second title
text.text: Chancellor Charles Bantz receives the additional title of executive vice president of Indiana University and the responsibility of overseeing the academic programs at IU's regional campuses.

text.headline: Suhkatme named Executive Vice Chancellor
text.text: Uday Suhkatme is named Executive Vice Chancellor of IUPUI.

text.headline: Katrina hits, Jags help
text.text: IUPUI is one of three universities to receive the inaugural Presidential Award by the Corporation for National and Community Service for exceptional accomplishments and distinction for Hurricane Katrina Relief.

text.headline: Providing free primary-care medical services to the near east side
text.text: IU Student Outreach Clinic opens on the near east side to provide free primary-care medical services. The clinic is a partnership with the schools of Medicine, Law, Social Work, Dentistry, Health and Rehabilitation Sciences, and Nursing.

text.headline: Collecting works by Ray Bradbury
text.text: The School of Liberal Arts creates the Center for Ray Bradbury Studies and begins to collect the author's published papers.

text.headline: Medical magnet school partnership
text.text: IUPUI signs a Memorandum of Understanding with Indianapolis Public Schools Crispus Attucks Medical Magnet School and Early College as a means to enhance opportunities for promising high school students and the IUPUI campus.

text.headline: The world's first healthy breast tissue bank
text.text: Susan G. Komen for the Cure awards $1 million to establish the Komen Tissue Bank at the IU Simon Cancer Center, the world's first healthy breast tissue bank.

text.headline: Bringing food, jobs, and treatments to Kenya
text.text: The IU School of Medicine's partnership with the Moi University School of Medicine in the east African nation of Kenya was nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize in 2007. The Academic Model for Prevention and Treatment of HIV/AIDS (AMPATH) treated more than 40,000 HIV-positive Kenyan patients at 19 clinics throughout the country's western region. The hospital site also included nearby fields and workshops that provided food, jobs, and agricultural assistance, decreasing the social stigma of the disease's victims and increasing their self sufficiency.

text.headline: Neal-Marshall alumni create Indianapolis chapter
text.text: The Indianapolis chapter of the Neal-Marshall Alumni Club forms.

text.headline: Campus Center opens
text.text: The Campus Center is completed and dedicated in April, becoming the hub of student life and serving as a one-stop destination for students, faculty, and staff.

text.headline: Accelerating research discoveries and public engagement
text.text: The Indiana Clinical and Translational Sciences Institute (CTSI) is formed as a partnership between Indiana University, Purdue University, and the University of Notre Dame to accelerate research discoveries across Indiana and beyond. In the same year, the Community Health Engagement Partnership is launched to encourage public engagement.

text.headline: RISE begins
text.text: The RISE Initiative begins under Executive Vice Chancellor Uday Sukhatme. Representing research, international travel and learning, service, and experiential learning, RISE engages students more deeply and contributes to their intellectual and professional development in unique ways.

text.headline: Top five best neighbors
text.text: IUPUI is recognized as one of the top five 'Best Neighbor' colleges and universities in the nation at the annual conference of the Coalition of Urban and Metropolitan Universities.

text.headline: The New Oxford Shakespeare
text.text: English professor Terri Bourus joins an international scholarly team to create The New Oxford Shakespeare, an entirely new print and digital edition of the complete works of Shakespeare, carefully using all the surviving original documents to provide Shakespearean spelling or modern spelling; a print or digital presentation; and alternative early versions of some works, among other options. Bourus serves as one of three general editors.

text.headline: You gotta Regatta
text.text: The IUPUI Regatta is born. It quickly becomes one of the city's most significant downtown events each September.

text.headline: Glick Eye Institute construction begins
text.text: Construction begins on the Eugene and Marilyn Glick Eye Institute at the corner of Michigan and West Streets. The four-story, 70,000-square-foot building houses the IU School of Medicine's Department of Ophthalmology. Half the building is dedicated clinic space and half is dedicated to biomedical research so new treatments can be developed for glaucoma, diabetic retinopathy, macular degeneration, and other causes of vision loss in adults and children.

text.headline: Service learning programs send dentistry students to Mexico and Montana
text.text: The School of Dentistry, the only dental school in Indiana, begins two new intercultural service learning programs—one in Mexico's Yucatan, the other in Montana—working with the Blackfeet Nation.

text.headline: The first Honors Scholars
text.text: The IUPUI Honors College welcomes its first cohort of students.

text.headline: Veteran services expand
text.text: With more student veterans and military personnel than any other Indiana college or university, IUPUI expands student services by opening the Office for Veterans and Military Personnel.

text.headline: Research to improve water quality in freshwater lakes and reservoirs
text.text: Professor Lenore Tedesco and her colleagues at the Center for Earth and Environmental Sciences conduct extensive research on blue-green algal blooms, which degrade water quality in freshwater lakes and reservoirs, with implications for public health, recreation, and the economy.

text.headline: Biocomputing degree offered
text.text: The School of Science introduces a new degree program in biocomputing to prepare students for medical careers in a rapidly growing field. Integrating computer science, biology, medicine, and informatics, the interdisciplinary program is the only one of its kind in the state and one of only a few pre-medical computer science programs in the country.

text.headline: A center for multicultural success
text.text: The Multicultural Center has its grand opening.

text.headline: Harvey Milk Dinner
text.text: The first Harvey Milk Dinner, organized by the GLBT Faculty and Staff Council, is held to celebrate the IUPUI LGBTQ+ community.

text.headline: Preserving Black history
text.text: In 2011, University Library took on the task of digitizing the Indianapolis Recorder, a newspaper of the city's African-American community from 1897 to 2005. The newspaper began as a two-page church bulletin and became one of the top African-American publications in the nation. The digitized collection allows researchers to search for and access historically important stories of African-American culture, people, organizations, and events in Indianapolis in the 20th and 21st centuries.

text.headline: Building a better workforce
text.text: IUPUI launches the Talent Alliance, a collective impact model that brings together dozens of local agencies and organizations focused on producing a highly educated and competitive workforce.

text.headline: The first school of philanthropy in the world
text.text: The Lilly Family School of Philanthropy is established. It is the first such school in the world and is named for one of America's great philanthropic families in honor of their generations of generosity and leadership.

text.headline: Planning begins on Hine Hall
text.text: The former University Place Conference Center and Hotel is transformed into a multi-use facility designed to provide student housing, residential and campus dining, and additional classroom space. The conversion begins after nearly a yearlong study of the complex and its viability by campus and IU officials. Hine Hall opens in January, followed by University Tower and Tower Dining in August.

text.headline: Fairbanks School of Public Health established
text.text: The Richard M. Fairbanks School of Public Health is established. Focusing on urban health, the school brings together faculty with expertise in health policy, epidemiology, biostatistics, environmental health, and social and behavioral health science.

text.headline: Eskenazi Fine Arts Center opens
text.text: The Eskenazi Fine Arts Center opens on Indiana Avenue. An expansion of a 12-year-old facility formerly known as the Herron Sculpture and Ceramics Building, the fine arts center includes a large, multipurpose studio for creating public art projects, as well as graduate studios, classrooms, galleries, and a computer lab.

text.headline: Lavender Graduation
text.text: The first Lavender Graduation is held, organized by the GLBT Faculty and Staff Council, to celebrate LGBTQ+ graduating students.

text.headline: Paw's Pantry opens
text.text: Paw's Pantry opens to address food insecurity among members of the IUPUI community.

text.headline: IUPUI Impact Campaign ends
text.text: The IUPUI Impact Campaign ends successfully, raising $1 billion.

text.headline: Student housing grows
text.text: Hine Hall, University Tower, and Tower Dining open in August, providing residential space for 560 students and dining space capacity for 470.

text.headline: Science and Engineering Lab Building is dedicated
text.text: The Science and Engineering Lab Building is dedicated in November. It is the first non-medical science building to open on the IUPUI campus in 20 years and contains more than 35,000 assignable square feet for research and teaching spaces. The first phase includes space for biomedical engineering, psychobiology, renewable energy research programs, and biology and chemistry labs. The second phase provides space for teaching labs, meeting rooms, additional expansions, more research laboratories, and administrative offices.

text.headline: Play ball
text.text: The men's basketball team begins to play in the Indiana Farmers Coliseum in the Indiana State Fairgrounds.

text.headline: Paydar takes the reins
text.text: Nasser H. Paydar, Ph.D., is named fifth chancellor of IUPUI.

text.headline: Nasser Paydar
text.text: As chancellor, I look forward to building on the momentum we have established at IUPUI and developing and implementing IUPUI's long-term vision, built on the success of our students, to fulfill the campus's commitment to Indiana and beyond. IUPUI Chancellor Nasser Paydar, 2015

text.headline: Deepening campus commitment
text.text: As part of his strategic plan, Chancellor Nasser Paydar includes the goal of 'Deepening Campus Commitment to Community Engagement.' The Office of External Affairs, Community Learning Network, Solution Center, and Center for Service and Learning are brought together to form the Office of Community Engagement.

text.headline: Smart Cities
text.text: IUPUI signs a Memorandum of Understanding with the City of Indianapolis to pursue Smart Cities initiatives that use technology and analytics to address problems facing the systems and infrastructure of the city.

text.headline: Awards for community engagement
text.text: The Charles R. Bantz Chancellor's Community Fellowship and Community Scholar awards are established to support community-engaged research.

media.caption: CAPTION: Lorem lorem Amet consectetur Adipiscing elit eiusmod incididunt ut Labore dolore

text.headline: Campus Compact Presidential Reception
text.text: The Center for Service and Learning celebrates its 25th anniversary by co-sponsoring the national Campus Compact Presidential Reception, hosting the 10th Annual Research Academy, and capturing stories of engagement over the years.

text.headline: Engagement at an all-time high
text.text: As of January 2015, 9,737 students, 875 community partners, and 390 faculty members participated in more than 1,200 community-based learning courses at IUPUI.

text.headline: LGBTQ+ Center is born
text.text: The LGBTQ+ Center is established to provide support, resources, education and community for IUPUI students, faculty and staff.

text.headline: Think it. Make it.
text.text: A new lab that merges technology and creative processes opens in the Herron School of Art and Design. The Think It Make It Lab helps students become better informed about the broad applications of design, production, and digital fabrication, including concept design and prototyping.

text.headline: Mid-North Promise Program
text.text: IUPUI signs a Memorandum of Understanding with the Childrens Museum of Indianapolis in support of a neighborhood-based education and career initiative known as the Mid-North Promise Program.

text.headline: Natatorium updates attract Olympic swimmers
text.text: IUPUI welcomes Olympic swimmers David Boudia, Kelci Bryant, and Mary Beth Dunnichay to the rededication of the IU Natatorium. Renovations include a new roof, new lighting, and many other improvements.

text.headline: North Hall opens
text.text: North Hall opens in August, providing housing for 700 students.

text.headline: Ball Garden reclaims its purpose
text.text: President Michael McRobbie, Chancellor Nasser Paydar, and School of Nursing Dean Robin Newhouse rededicate the refurbished Ball Nurses Sunken Garden on the IUPUI campus. Conceived in 1929, the garden was designed as a therapeutic space for patients at Riley Hospital for Children, their families, and the hardworking nurses who served them. It also became a gathering place to celebrate graduations, pinning ceremonies, and other nursing student traditions.

text.headline: Dressing up Flo
text.text: At the center of Ball Nurses Sunken Garden stands a statue of Eve. The statue was commissioned by the IU Alumni Nurses Association in 1931, and they nicknamed her “Flo,” for Florence Nightingale. It became tradition to dress the sculpture and pose for photos with her at graduation time. Eve was returned to her rightful spot in the garden's fountain as part of the restoration.

text.headline: Creating a welcoming campus for all
text.text: IUPUI launches the Welcoming Campus Initiative, designed to make faculty, staff, students, and the community feel more welcomed, included, and inspired on campus.

media.caption: CAPTION: Lorem sit consectetur Sed Tempor incididunt Labore et dolore Aliqua enim ad quis Nostrud exercitation nisi

text.headline: Into the Horizon League
text.text: IUPUI Jaguar Athletics moves to the Horizon League. In their first season, the women's soccer team wins the league championship and goes on to the NCAA tournament.

text.headline: Softball champions
text.text: The Women's Softball team wins the Summit League Championship.

text.headline: Top 20 most innovative
text.text: IUPUI is named among the top 20 most innovative universities in the country by U.S. News & World Report.

text.headline: Into the Horizon League
text.text: IUPUI Jaguar Athletics moves to the Horizon League. In their first season, the women's soccer team wins the league championship and goes on to the NCAA tournament.

text.headline: Improving the well-being of Latino populations in Indiana
text.text: IUPUI hosts the first annual Latinx Community–University Research Coalition, with the goal of fostering connections and improving the well-being of Latino populations in Indiana.

text.headline: Culture of Health
text.text: The Office of Community Engagement facilitates a Culture of Health leadership team in partnership with the Mary Rigg Neighborhood Center to address health needs at area schools.

text.headline: Anchor Housing Program launches
text.text: As part of its anchor institution role, IUPUI launches the Anchor Housing Program to provide incentives for employees to purchase or rehabilitate a home near campus.

text.headline: Spurring economic vitality on the Near West Side
text.text: The Office of Community Engagement launches the SOURCE River West Entrepreneurship Center in the Near West neighborhood as a means to spur economic vitality of the community.

text.headline: Honoring Madam C.J. Walker
text.text: Indiana University partners with the Madam Walker Theater Center to honor the legacy of Madam C.J. Walker and create a more sustainable future for the Center.

text.headline: Horizon League win for Women's Soccer
text.text: The Women's Soccer team wins the Horizon League Championship Title after beating the Milwaukee Panthers in a 4-3 overtime shoot out.

media.caption: CAPTION: lorem sit Amet consectetur elit Sed magna Aliqua Ut veniam Nostrud exercitation laboris

text.headline: University Hall Opens
text.text: University Hall is home to the IU Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and also offers critically needed additional space for the IU School of Social Work. It also serves as the home to IUPUI administration, the IUPUI Office of Alumni Relations, and the IU Foundation.

text.headline: 25 years of CSL
text.text: The Center for Service and Learning celebrates its 25th anniversary by co-sponsoring the national Campus Compact Presidential Reception, hosting the 10th Annual Research Academy, and capturing stories of engagement over the years.

text.headline: Sunken Gardens Rededicated
text.text: President Michael McRobbie, Chancellor Nasser Paydar, and School of Nursing Dean Robin Newhouse rededicate the refurbished Ball Nurses Sunken Garden on the IUPUI campus.
text.secondary_text: Conceived in 1929, the garden was designed as a therapeutic space for patients at Riley Hospital for Children, their families, and the hardworking nurses who served them. It also became a gathering place to celebrate graduations, pinning ceremonies, and other nursing student traditions.

text.headline: Nasser H. Paydar, Ph.D.
text.text: Nasser H. Paydar, Ph.D., is named fifth chancellor of IUPUI.

text.headline: Preserving Black history
text.text: University Library took on the task of digitizing the Indianapolis Recorder, a newspaper of the city's African-American community from 1897 to 2005.
text.secondary_text: In 2011, University Library took on the task of digitizing the Indianapolis Recorder, a newspaper of the city's African-American community from 1897 to 2005. The newspaper began as a two-page church bulletin and became one of the top African-American publications in the nation. The digitized collection allows researchers to search for and access historically important stories of African-American culture, people, organizations, and events in Indianapolis in the 20th and 21st centuries.

text.headline: Hine Hall
text.text: The former University Place Conference Center and Hotel is transformed into a multi-use facility designed to provide student housing, residential and campus dining, and additional classroom space.

text.headline: Hine Chancellorship
text.text: Maynard K. Hine was the first chancellor of IUPUI and the first Hoosier elected president of the American Dental Association.

text.headline: Irwin Chancellorship
text.text: During Glenn Irwin Jr., M.D.'s chancellorship, IUPUI's visibility and respectability as an academic institution increased dramatically.

text.headline: Bepko Chancellorship
text.text: Gerald L. Bepko joined the faculty of the Indiana University School of Law at IUPUI in 1972, becoming a full professor in 1975.

text.headline: Bantz Chancellorship
text.text: Charles Bantz became the fourth chancellor of IUPUI in 2003, guiding the IUPUI campus through a period of growth and unprecedented student success.

text.headline: Paydar Chancellorship
text.text: Nasser H. Paydar, Ph.D., is named fifth chancellor of IUPUI in 2015
